_context_left: Proofpoint researchers in the [sixth](/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-gift-carding "BEC Taxonomy: Gift Carding ") of the [Business Email Compromise](/us/threat-reference/business-email-compromise "Business Email Compromise (BEC)") (BEC) taxonomy series explored the gift carding theme from the
sentence_left: ### Last Time in the BEC Taxonomy Series…
sentence_right: Gift carding is a fairly common form of email fraud that relies heavily on familiarity and, like the final theme we will explore, a sense of urgency to override any hesitation on the part of the victims to get them to fall for the fraud.
label: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns. Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.

sentence_left: Once the victim provides the small amount of money to the fraudster, however, they cut all contact and disappear.
sentence_right: Advance Fee Fraud leverages impersonation from the Deception layer of the Email Fraud Taxonomy.

sentence_right: While Advance Fee only makes up a small fraction of the fraud emails Proofpoint researchers see in a day, the average loss can still be about $5,100 per incident when someone does fall for them.

sentence_left: Most Advance Fee Fraud emails are simple and easy to spot as fraudulent with few being well-crafted and more complex than the examples provided above.
sentence_right: Relying on greed and a sense of urgency, Advance Fee Fraud can be lucrative for threat actors, although their success rate is probably not nearly as high as it is in previously discussed themes such as gift carding.
label: Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. sentence_right: In figure 5, the threat actor tries to tempt the victim with a large beneficiary payment—a common strategy in this type of fraud—in the hopes that they can capitalize on the victim’s greed and get them to share personally identifiable information as well as pay a small amount of money.
label: No Annotation

mention: Once the victim provides the small amount of money to the fraudster, however, they cut all contact and disappear.
sentence_left: The fraudsters often bait victims with subjects such as inheritance, lottery winnings, awards, government payouts, and international business.
sentence_right: ### Advance Fee Fraud and the Email Fraud Taxonomy Framework
label: No Annotation

sentence_right: Advance Fee Fraud emails use a variety of lures to convince recipients of their legitimacy and to entice them to follow through on the request.
label: No Annotation

mention: Relying on greed and a sense of urgency, Advance Fee Fraud can be lucrative for threat actors, although their success rate is probably not nearly as high as it is in previously discussed themes such as gift carding.
sentence_left: While Advance Fee only makes up a small fraction of the fraud emails Proofpoint researchers see in a day, the average loss can still be about $5,100 per incident when someone does fall for them.

sentence_left: Advance Fee Fraud leverages impersonation from the Deception layer of the Email Fraud Taxonomy.
sentence_right: Most Advance Fee Fraud emails use display name spoofing, as illustrated in Figure 2, to deceive recipients.
label: No Annotation

sentence_left: To a lesser extent threat actors will use the other impersonation tactics, such as spoofing the domain or using a lookalike domain.
label: No Annotation

sentence_left: Relying on greed and a sense of urgency, Advance Fee Fraud can be lucrative for threat actors, although their success rate is probably not nearly as high as it is in previously discussed themes such as gift carding.
sentence_right: To better understand Proofpoint’s approach to BEC and how our researchers think of the various fraud themes, take a look at the first blog in this series, [BEC Taxonomy: A Proofpoint Framework](/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-proofpoint-framework "BEC Taxonomy: A Proofpoint Framework").
label: No Annotation
